Datasets:Â 
We use five benchmark datasets in our experiments, comprising four image datasets and one text dataset. TableÂ 1 provides an overview of the dataset statistics.

FL training settings:Â  Following prior workÂ [9, 4], we assume 100 clients in total. A unique characteristic of FL is that the local training data are not identically distributed (non-iid) across clients. We use the method inÂ [4] to simulate non-iid settings, and the degree of non-iid is set to 0.5 for CIFAR-10, Fashion-MNIST, MNIST, and ImageNet-Fruits. The details of simulating non-iid can be found in AppendixÂ A.6. For the Sentiment140 dataset, we divide the users into 100 groups uniformly at random. Each group is considered as a client, whose local training data is the union of the training tweets of the users in the group. Usersâ€™ tweets are non-iid, so the clientsâ€™ local training data are also non-iid. Therefore, we do not need to simulate the non-iid setting for this dataset. We train a ResNet-20Â [30] classifier for CIFAR-10, a CNN classifier for Fashion-MNIST and MNIST (the architecture is shown in TableÂ 15 in Appendix), a LSTMÂ [31] classifier for Sentiment140, and a ResNet-50Â [30] classifier for ImageNet-Fruits dataset.

The default parameter settings (e.g., learning rates, batch sizes, global rounds, and local training epochs) are shown in TableÂ 16 in Appendix. By default, the server selects all clients in each training round and uses the average aggregation rule FedAvgÂ [1] to aggregate the clientsâ€™ model updates. However, we will explore the impact of the fraction of selected clients in a training round and aggregation rule on FLForensics.

Training-phase defenses are insufficient:Â  Training-phase defenses use robust FL methods or malicious-client detection methods to prevent malicious clients from poisoning a global model during training. TableÂ 18 in Appendix shows that robust FL methodsâ€“such as TrimÂ [7], MedianÂ [7], FLTrustÂ [9], and FLAMEÂ [8]â€“are insufficient. In particular, ASRs of the considered poisoning attacks are still high in many cases. TableÂ 2 shows that FLDetector, a malicious-client detection method, cannot accurately detect malicious clients during training in many cases. These training-phase defenses are still vulnerable to poisoning attacks because the clientsâ€™ training data are non-iid, making it hard to accurately distinguish between malicious clientsâ€™ and benign clientsâ€™ model updates.

FLForensicsÂ outperforms the compared poison-forensics methods:Â 
TableÂ 3 also shows that our FLForensicsÂ outperforms the compared poison-forensics methods. First, FLForensicsÂ outperforms FLForensics-A, particularly evident in FLForensicsâ€™s significantly lower FPR compared to FLForensics-A. For instance, FLForensicsÂ exhibits a FPR of 0 under all attacks on CIFAR-10, while FLForensics-Aâ€™s FPR consistently exceeds 10%, indicating that at least 8 benign clients are incorrectly classified as malicious clients by FLForensics-A. This result demonstrates that using only the target input xğ‘¥{x} is unable to distinguish between malicious and Category I benign clients. Second, FLForensicsÂ outperforms PF and FLForensics-G because they were not designed for FL. In our comparison, we give advantages to FLForensics-G and PF by assuming that they have access to the local training data. We also conduct experiments where they use clientsâ€™ model updates sent to the server. TableÂ 17 in Appendix shows the results. We can observe that FLForensics-G performs worse, while PF achieves similar performance to using the local training data.

Impact of aggregation rules:Â  Based on TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ can accurately trace back the malicious clients when the server uses different Byzantine-robust aggregation rules during training. We note that these Byzantine-robust aggregation rules are not effective at defending against the poisoning attacks in our experimental settings, as shown in TableÂ 18 in Appendix.
Our results show that FLForensicsÂ is complementary with training-phase defenses and can be used together with them.
In TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ achieves slightly higher FPR when FLAME is used as the aggregation rule. This is because Scaling attack is less effective for FLAME and FLForensicsÂ incorrectly identifies some Category I benign clients as malicious.

Impact of fraction of selected clients:Â Based on TableÂ 10, FLForensicsÂ works well even if the server selects a small fraction of clients in each training round. The reason is that once a malicious client appears in multiple check-point training rounds, FLForensicsÂ can accumulate its influences to distinguish it with benign clients. Note that in this experiment, we save all training rounds as check points so a malicious client appears in multiple of them.

Impact of scaling factor Î³ğ›¾\gamma:Â  Based on the results in TableÂ 10, we observe that FLForensicsÂ works well for a wide range of scaling factors used by the Scaling attack. The reason is that once the Scaling attack is effective, FLForensicsÂ can identify the malicious clients. Previous workÂ [16] shows that the higher the scaling factor, the more effective the attack, but it also makes the attack more susceptible to detection. We can observe that our FLForensicsÂ can detect all the malicious clients even when the scaling factor is close to 1. In such cases, methods (e.g., FLDetector) that rely on the magnitudes of clientsâ€™ model updates to detect malicious clients often fail.

Attack frequency:Â 
One adaptive attack is that each malicious client performs attacks only in some certain selected training rounds, violating the poisoning attack definition in DefinitionÂ 1. In particular, when a malicious client does not perform attack in a training round, it calculates its model update based on the clean local training data. TableÂ 11a shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the malicious clients perform the Scaling attack in every eğ‘’e training rounds, where eğ‘’e ranges from 1 to 10.
We find that when the malicious clients perform attack every 10 or more rounds, FLForensicsÂ cannot accurately detect the malicious clients. This is because the attacks are ineffective, i.e., ASRs are less than 12%. In other words, FLForensicsÂ can accurately detect malicious clients for the adaptive attack once it is effective, i.e., attack frequently and achieve high ASRs.

Attack probability:Â 
Other than performing attacks periodically in every eğ‘’e training rounds, an attacker can also choose to perform attack in each training round with a certain probability. Such attack may be more stealthy and harder to trace back. TableÂ 11b shows the results when a malicious client launches the Scaling attack with a probability pğ‘p in each training round, where pğ‘p ranges from 0.2 to 1.0.
We observe that ASR decreases as pğ‘p decreases. FLForensicsÂ accurately detects malicious clients when pâ‰¥0.5ğ‘0.5p\geq 0.5, with a FPR not exceeding 1.25%. When p=0.2ğ‘0.2p=0.2, the attack has an ASR of 20%. Since the attack is less effective in this scenario, FLForensicsÂ has a higher FNR at detecting malicious clients. However, FLForensicsÂ still achieves a small FPR, with at most one benign client misclassified as malicious.

Trigger location:Â 
FollowingÂ [16], we place the trigger at the upper right corner of an image by default. TableÂ 11c illustrates the performance of FLForensicsÂ when the Scaling attack places the trigger at different locations, where UR, LR, UL, and LL represent the trigger is at the upper right corner, lower right corner, upper left corner, and lower left corner of an image, respectively. Note that the trigger in these experiments is the same as that inÂ [16].
We also evaluate adding the trigger at a random location of each image in each training round, which corresponds to the â€˜Randomâ€™ row. The results show that when the triggerâ€™s location is fixed, the attack is generally more effective, with only the UL trigger location having a lower ASR, and FLForensicsÂ can correctly identify malicious clients in such scenarios. When the attacker introduces the trigger at random locations, the attack becomes less effective, and thus FLForensicsÂ misses some malicious clients (FNR is around 30%). Our results show that FLForensicsÂ performs well across various trigger locations that achieve high ASRs. We note that previous workÂ [34] showed that trigger location including random location does not have much impact on an attackâ€™s ASR. We have a different observation in our experiments. This is because the previous work was for centralized learning, while our results are for FL.

Trigger value:Â 
To investigate the performance of FLForensicsÂ under different trigger values, we vary the pixel value of the trigger, where the trigger shape is from Bagdasaryan et al.Â [16]. Specifically, we select three different RGB values for each pixel of the trigger, i.e., (255, 255, 255), (204, 204, 204), and (0, 0, 0). Additionally, we use a random trigger, each pixel of which has random RGB values. TableÂ 11e shows these triggers and the corresponding performance of FLForensics. Our results indicate that once the attack is effective, FLForensicsÂ can accurately trace back malicious clients. FLForensicsÂ misses all the malicious clients when the trigger value is (0, 0, 0). This is because this trigger value is ineffective at all, i.e., ASR=0.

Trigger size:Â 
TableÂ 11d shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the Scaling attack uses different trigger sizes, where the trigger is a white square located at the upper right corner. We observe that as the trigger size increases, ASR also increases. When the trigger size is 2Ã—\times2, the attack has almost no effect, leading to inaccurate detection of malicious clients for FLForensics. However, when the trigger size is greater than or equal to 3Ã—\times3, FLForensicsÂ can correctly identify all malicious clients, even with an ASR of only 14.2%. These results show that once the trigger size is large enough to make the attack somewhat effective, our FLForensicsÂ performs well.

Using true input as non-target input:Â  In our experiments, we use a random input (e.g., a random image) as a non-target input in FLForensics. When a true input with the target label is available, the server can also use it as the non-target input. TableÂ 12 compares the results when FLForensicsÂ uses a random input or true input as the non-target input on the five datasets and three attacks.
We find that random inputs and true inputs achieve comparable results in most cases, except several cases, for which true inputs achieve slightly lower FPRs. These results indicate that if a true input with the target label from the learning taskâ€™s data distribution is available, the server can use it as the non-target input.

Extending FLForensicsÂ to centralized learning:Â  Our FLForensicsÂ can also be extended to centralized learning. In particular, we treat a training example as a â€œclientâ€; wtsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡w_{t} in EquationÂ 5 andÂ 6 is the model in the tğ‘¡tth mini-batch when training a model; and gt(i)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘–g_{t}^{(i)} is the gradient of the cross-entropy loss of wtsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡w_{t} for the iğ‘–ith training example. We find that when the training dataset is unbalanced (i.e., like non-iid in FL) and the target label is a class that has more training examples, FLForensicsÂ substantially outperforms existing poison-forensics methods for centralized learning. For instance, TableÂ 14 shows the results for different methods at tracing back the poisoned training examples, where FLForensics-True means using a true input as the non-target input. The dataset is sampled from CIFAR-10, where FigureÂ 5 in Appendix shows the distribution of training examples among the classes in our experiments. We performed a targeted poisoning attack to the dataset: the target label is 1; and we inject the trigger used in our FL experiments into 10% of the training inputs.

FLForensicsÂ is effective:Â  TableÂ 3 shows the results of FLForensicsÂ and compared poison-forensics methods under different attacks and datasets.
We observe that FLForensicsÂ can accurately identify malicious clients, achieving a DACC of 1 or nearly 1 in all experiments. The FPR of FLForensicsÂ is 0 or close to 0 in most cases, with four exceptions (Sentiment140 dataset under Scaling attack, Sentiment140 dataset under Edge attack, CIFAR-10 dataset under Edge attack, and ImageNet-Fruits dataset under Edge attack), for which FPR is around 3%, i.e., one to three benign clients are misclassified as malicious. Similarly, FNR is also 0 or close to 0, with only two exceptions.

FLForensicsÂ outperforms the compared poison-forensics methods:Â 
TableÂ 3 also shows that our FLForensicsÂ outperforms the compared poison-forensics methods. First, FLForensicsÂ outperforms FLForensics-A, particularly evident in FLForensicsâ€™s significantly lower FPR compared to FLForensics-A. For instance, FLForensicsÂ exhibits a FPR of 0 under all attacks on CIFAR-10, while FLForensics-Aâ€™s FPR consistently exceeds 10%, indicating that at least 8 benign clients are incorrectly classified as malicious clients by FLForensics-A. This result demonstrates that using only the target input xğ‘¥{x} is unable to distinguish between malicious and Category I benign clients. Second, FLForensicsÂ outperforms PF and FLForensics-G because they were not designed for FL. In our comparison, we give advantages to FLForensics-G and PF by assuming that they have access to the local training data. We also conduct experiments where they use clientsâ€™ model updates sent to the server. TableÂ 17 in Appendix shows the results. We can observe that FLForensics-G performs worse, while PF achieves similar performance to using the local training data.

Recovering from attacks after FLForensics:Â  After detecting malicious clients, a server can re-train a global model using the remaining clients to recover from attacks. We pick the case in TableÂ 3, for which FLForensicsÂ has the largest FNR, to show recovery results. On CIFAR-10 dataset under Edge attack, the original global model has testing accuracy 81.9% and ASR 17.4%; and after detecting malicious clients and re-training a global model, these numbers change to 82.8% and 5.6%, respectively. Note that the server can also re-train a global model with small communication/computation cost for the clients using FedRecoverÂ [18].

Impact of number of check points and storage overhead:Â  TableÂ 4 shows the impact of the number of check points on FLForensics. We observe a trade-off between storage overhead and poison-forensics performance. In particular, when a server saves more check points, which incurs more storage overhead, the server can more accurately detect the malicious clients. We also note that the storage overhead is acceptable for a powerful server to achieve good poison-forensics performance.
TableÂ 5 shows the storage overhead for different datasets in our default settings.
For instance, saving 150 check points for CIFAR-10 requires 15.22GB storage, which is acceptable for a powerful server like a data center.

In particular, when a malicious client does not perform attack in a training round, it calculates its model update based on the clean local training data. TableÂ 11a shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the malicious clients perform the Scaling attack in every eğ‘’e training rounds, where eğ‘’e ranges from 1 to 10.
We find that when the malicious clients perform attack every 10 or more rounds, FLForensicsÂ cannot accurately detect the malicious clients. This is because the attacks are ineffective, i.e., ASRs are less than 12%. In other words, FLForensicsÂ can accurately detect malicious clients for the adaptive attack once it is effective, i.e., attack frequently and achieve high ASRs.

Attack probability:Â 
Other than performing attacks periodically in every eğ‘’e training rounds, an attacker can also choose to perform attack in each training round with a certain probability. Such attack may be more stealthy and harder to trace back. TableÂ 11b shows the results when a malicious client launches the Scaling attack with a probability pğ‘p in each training round, where pğ‘p ranges from 0.2 to 1.0.
We observe that ASR decreases as pğ‘p decreases. FLForensicsÂ accurately detects malicious clients when pâ‰¥0.5ğ‘0.5p\geq 0.5, with a FPR not exceeding 1.25%. When p=0.2ğ‘0.2p=0.2, the attack has an ASR of 20%. Since the attack is less effective in this scenario, FLForensicsÂ has a higher FNR at detecting malicious clients. However, FLForensicsÂ still achieves a small FPR, with at most one benign client misclassified as malicious.

Trigger location:Â 
FollowingÂ [16], we place the trigger at the upper right corner of an image by default. TableÂ 11c illustrates the performance of FLForensicsÂ when the Scaling attack places the trigger at different locations, where UR, LR, UL, and LL represent the trigger is at the upper right corner, lower right corner, upper left corner, and lower left corner of an image, respectively. Note that the trigger in these experiments is the same as that inÂ [16].
We also evaluate adding the trigger at a random location of each image in each training round, which corresponds to the â€˜Randomâ€™ row. The results show that when the triggerâ€™s location is fixed, the attack is generally more effective, with only the UL trigger location having a lower ASR, and FLForensicsÂ can correctly identify malicious clients in such scenarios. When the attacker introduces the trigger at random locations, the attack becomes less effective, and thus FLForensicsÂ misses some malicious clients (FNR is around 30%). Our results show that FLForensicsÂ performs well across various trigger locations that achieve high ASRs. We note that previous workÂ [34] showed that trigger location including random location does not have much impact on an attackâ€™s ASR. We have a different observation in our experiments. This is because the previous work was for centralized learning, while our results are for FL.

Trigger value:Â 
To investigate the performance of FLForensicsÂ under different trigger values, we vary the pixel value of the trigger, where the trigger shape is from Bagdasaryan et al.Â [16]. Specifically, we select three different RGB values for each pixel of the trigger, i.e., (255, 255, 255), (204, 204, 204), and (0, 0, 0). Additionally, we use a random trigger, each pixel of which has random RGB values. TableÂ 11e shows these triggers and the corresponding performance of FLForensics. Our results indicate that once the attack is effective, FLForensicsÂ can accurately trace back malicious clients. FLForensicsÂ misses all the malicious clients when the trigger value is (0, 0, 0). This is because this trigger value is ineffective at all, i.e., ASR=0.

Trigger size:Â 
TableÂ 11d shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the Scaling attack uses different trigger sizes, where the trigger is a white square located at the upper right corner. We observe that as the trigger size increases, ASR also increases. When the trigger size is 2Ã—\times2, the attack has almost no effect, leading to inaccurate detection of malicious clients for FLForensics. However, when the trigger size is greater than or equal to 3Ã—\times3, FLForensicsÂ can correctly identify all malicious clients, even with an ASR of only 14.2%. These results show that once the trigger size is large enough to make the attack somewhat effective, our FLForensicsÂ performs well.

These results indicate that if a true input with the target label from the learning taskâ€™s data distribution is available, the server can use it as the non-target input.

We use five benchmark datasets in our experiments, comprising four image datasets and one text dataset. TableÂ 1 provides an overview of the dataset statistics.

FL training settings:Â  Following prior workÂ [9, 4], we assume 100 clients in total. A unique characteristic of FL is that the local training data are not identically distributed (non-iid) across clients. We use the method inÂ [4] to simulate non-iid settings, and the degree of non-iid is set to 0.5 for CIFAR-10, Fashion-MNIST, MNIST, and ImageNet-Fruits. The details of simulating non-iid can be found in AppendixÂ A.6. For the Sentiment140 dataset, we divide the users into 100 groups uniformly at random. Each group is considered as a client, whose local training data is the union of the training tweets of the users in the group. Usersâ€™ tweets are non-iid, so the clientsâ€™ local training data are also non-iid. Therefore, we do not need to simulate the non-iid setting for this dataset. We train a ResNet-20Â [30] classifier for CIFAR-10, a CNN classifier for Fashion-MNIST and MNIST (the architecture is shown in TableÂ 15 in Appendix), a LSTMÂ [31] classifier for Sentiment140, and a ResNet-50Â [30] classifier for ImageNet-Fruits dataset.

The default parameter settings (e.g., learning rates, batch sizes, global rounds, and local training epochs) are shown in TableÂ 16 in Appendix. By default, the server selects all clients in each training round and uses the average aggregation rule FedAvgÂ [1] to aggregate the clientsâ€™ model updates. However, we will explore the impact of the fraction of selected clients in a training round and aggregation rule on FLForensics.

Training-phase defenses are insufficient:Â  Training-phase defenses use robust FL methods or malicious-client detection methods to prevent malicious clients from poisoning a global model during training. TableÂ 18 in Appendix shows that robust FL methodsâ€“such as TrimÂ [7], MedianÂ [7], FLTrustÂ [9], and FLAMEÂ [8]â€“are insufficient. In particular, ASRs of the considered poisoning attacks are still high in many cases. TableÂ 2 shows that FLDetector, a malicious-client detection method, cannot accurately detect malicious clients during training in many cases. These training-phase defenses are still vulnerable to poisoning attacks because the clientsâ€™ training data are non-iid, making it hard to accurately distinguish between malicious clientsâ€™ and benign clientsâ€™ model updates.

FLForensicsÂ is effective:Â  TableÂ 3 shows the results of FLForensicsÂ and compared poison-forensics methods under different attacks and datasets.
We observe that FLForensicsÂ can accurately identify malicious clients, achieving a DACC of 1 or nearly 1 in all experiments. The FPR of FLForensicsÂ is 0 or close to 0 in most cases, with four exceptions (Sentiment140 dataset under Scaling attack, Sentiment140 dataset under Edge attack, CIFAR-10 dataset under Edge attack, and ImageNet-Fruits dataset under Edge attack), for which FPR is around 3%, i.e., one to three benign clients are misclassified as malicious. Similarly, FNR is also 0 or close to 0, with only two exceptions.

FLForensicsÂ outperforms the compared poison-forensics methods:Â 
TableÂ 3 also shows that our FLForensicsÂ outperforms the compared poison-forensics methods. First, FLForensicsÂ outperforms FLForensics-A, particularly evident in FLForensicsâ€™s significantly lower FPR compared to FLForensics-A. For instance, FLForensicsÂ exhibits a FPR of 0 under all attacks on CIFAR-10, while FLForensics-Aâ€™s FPR consistently exceeds 10%, indicating that at least 8 benign clients are incorrectly classified as malicious clients by FLForensics-A. This result demonstrates that using only the target input xğ‘¥{x} is unable to distinguish between malicious and Category I benign clients. Second, FLForensicsÂ outperforms PF and FLForensics-G because they were not designed for FL. In our comparison, we give advantages to FLForensics-G and PF by assuming that they have access to the local training data. We also conduct experiments where they use clientsâ€™ model updates sent to the server. TableÂ 17 in Appendix shows the results. We can observe that FLForensics-G performs worse, while PF achieves similar performance to using the local training data.

Impact of number of check points and storage overhead:Â  TableÂ 4 shows the impact of the number of check points on FLForensics. We observe a trade-off between storage overhead and poison-forensics performance. In particular, when a server saves more check points, which incurs more storage overhead, the server can more accurately detect the malicious clients. We also note that the storage overhead is acceptable for a powerful server to achieve good poison-forensics performance.
TableÂ 5 shows the storage overhead for different datasets in our default settings.
For instance, saving 150 check points for CIFAR-10 requires 15.22GB storage, which is acceptable for a powerful server like a data center.

Impact of fraction of malicious clients:Â TableÂ 6 shows the impact of fraction of malicious clients on FLForensics. We observe that FLForensicsÂ works well when a large fraction of clients are malicious. For instance, only 5% of malicious clients are identified as benign even if 40% of clients are malicious. Moreover, all benign clients are correctly detected as benign (i.e., FPR=0) when the fraction of malicious clients varies from 10% to 40%. We note that when the fraction of malicious clients is small, the attacks are not effectiveÂ [4], and thus we consider at least 10% of malicious clients.

Impact of degree of non-iid:Â  Based on the results in TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ works well across different degrees of non-iid. In particular, FLForensicsÂ achieves 0 FPR and at most 15% FNR across different settings of degree of non-iid. Note that 0.1 degree of non-iid represents the iid setting. FLForensicsÂ works well for non-iid because it is explicitly designed to take non-iid into consideration.

Impact of aggregation rules:Â  Based on TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ can accurately trace back the malicious clients when the server uses different Byzantine-robust aggregation rules during training. We note that these Byzantine-robust aggregation rules are not effective at defending against the poisoning attacks in our experimental settings, as shown in TableÂ 18 in Appendix.
Our results show that FLForensicsÂ is complementary with training-phase defenses and can be used together with them.
In TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ achieves slightly higher FPR when FLAME is used as the aggregation rule. This is because Scaling attack is less effective for FLAME and FLForensicsÂ incorrectly identifies some Category I benign clients as malicious.

The reason is that once a malicious client appears in multiple check-point training rounds, FLForensicsÂ can accumulate its influences to distinguish it with benign clients. Note that in this experiment, we save all training rounds as check points so a malicious client appears in multiple of them.

The reason is that once the Scaling attack is effective, FLForensicsÂ can identify the malicious clients. Previous workÂ [16] shows that the higher the scaling factor, the more effective the attack, but it also makes the attack more susceptible to detection. We can observe that our FLForensicsÂ can detect all the malicious clients even when the scaling factor is close to 1. Impact of fraction of selected clients:Â Based on TableÂ 10, FLForensicsÂ works well even if the server selects a small fraction of clients in each training round. The reason is that once a malicious client appears in multiple check-point training rounds, FLForensicsÂ can accumulate its influences to distinguish it with benign clients. Note that in this experiment, we save all training rounds as check points so a malicious client appears in multiple of them.

The reason is that once the Scaling attack is effective, FLForensicsÂ can identify the malicious clients. We can observe that our FLForensicsÂ can detect all the malicious clients even when the scaling factor is close to 1. We pick the case in TableÂ 3, for which FLForensicsÂ has the largest FNR, to show recovery results. On CIFAR-10 dataset under Edge attack, the original global model has testing accuracy 81.9% and ASR 17.4%; and after detecting malicious clients and re-training a global model, these numbers change to 82.8% and 5.6%, respectively. Note that the server can also re-train a global model with small communication/computation cost for the clients using FedRecoverÂ [18].

Attack frequency:Â 
One adaptive attack is that each malicious client performs attacks only in some certain selected training rounds, violating the poisoning attack definition in DefinitionÂ 1. In particular, when a malicious client does not perform attack in a training round, it calculates its model update based on the clean local training data. TableÂ 11a shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the malicious clients perform the Scaling attack in every eğ‘’e training rounds, where eğ‘’e ranges from 1 to 10.
We find that when the malicious clients perform attack every 10 or more rounds, FLForensicsÂ cannot accurately detect the malicious clients. This is because the attacks are ineffective, i.e., ASRs are less than 12%. In other words, FLForensicsÂ can accurately detect malicious clients for the adaptive attack once it is effective, i.e., attack frequently and achieve high ASRs.

Attack probability:Â 
Other than performing attacks periodically in every eğ‘’e training rounds, an attacker can also choose to perform attack in each training round with a certain probability. Such attack may be more stealthy and harder to trace back. TableÂ 11b shows the results when a malicious client launches the Scaling attack with a probability pğ‘p in each training round, where pğ‘p ranges from 0.2 to 1.0.
We observe that ASR decreases as pğ‘p decreases. FLForensicsÂ accurately detects malicious clients when pâ‰¥0.5ğ‘0.5p\geq 0.5, with a FPR not exceeding 1.25%. When p=0.2ğ‘0.2p=0.2, the attack has an ASR of 20%. Since the attack is less effective in this scenario, FLForensicsÂ has a higher FNR at detecting malicious clients. However, FLForensicsÂ still achieves a small FPR, with at most one benign client misclassified as malicious.

FollowingÂ [16], we place the trigger at the upper right corner of an image by default. The results show that when the triggerâ€™s location is fixed, the attack is generally more effective, with only the UL trigger location having a lower ASR, and FLForensicsÂ can correctly identify malicious clients in such scenarios. When the attacker introduces the trigger at random locations, the attack becomes less effective, and thus FLForensicsÂ misses some malicious clients (FNR is around 30%). Our results show that FLForensicsÂ performs well across various trigger locations that achieve high ASRs. We note that previous workÂ [34] showed that trigger location including random location does not have much impact on an attackâ€™s ASR. We have a different observation in our experiments. This is because the previous work was for centralized learning, while our results are for FL.

To investigate the performance of FLForensicsÂ under different trigger values, we vary the pixel value of the trigger, where the trigger shape is from Bagdasaryan et al.Â [16]. Specifically, we select three different RGB values for each pixel of the trigger, i.e., (255, 255, 255), (204, 204, 204), and (0, 0, 0). Additionally, we use a random trigger, each pixel of which has random RGB values. TableÂ 11e shows these triggers and the corresponding performance of FLForensics. TableÂ 11d shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the Scaling attack uses different trigger sizes, where the trigger is a white square located at the upper right corner. We observe that as the trigger size increases, ASR also increases. However, when the trigger size is greater than or equal to 3Ã—\times3, FLForensicsÂ can correctly identify all malicious clients, even with an ASR of only 14.2%. Datasets:Â 
We use five benchmark datasets in our experiments, comprising four image datasets and one text dataset. TableÂ 1 provides an overview of the dataset statistics.

FL training settings:Â  Following prior workÂ [9, 4], we assume 100 clients in total. A unique characteristic of FL is that the local training data are not identically distributed (non-iid) across clients. We use the method inÂ [4] to simulate non-iid settings, and the degree of non-iid is set to 0.5 for CIFAR-10, Fashion-MNIST, MNIST, and ImageNet-Fruits. The details of simulating non-iid can be found in AppendixÂ A.6. For the Sentiment140 dataset, we divide the users into 100 groups uniformly at random. Each group is considered as a client, whose local training data is the union of the training tweets of the users in the group. Usersâ€™ tweets are non-iid, so the clientsâ€™ local training data are also non-iid. Therefore, we do not need to simulate the non-iid setting for this dataset. We train a ResNet-20Â [30] classifier for CIFAR-10, a CNN classifier for Fashion-MNIST and MNIST (the architecture is shown in TableÂ 15 in Appendix), a LSTMÂ [31] classifier for Sentiment140, and a ResNet-50Â [30] classifier for ImageNet-Fruits dataset.

The default parameter settings (e.g., learning rates, batch sizes, global rounds, and local training epochs) are shown in TableÂ 16 in Appendix. By default, the server selects all clients in each training round and uses the average aggregation rule FedAvgÂ [1] to aggregate the clientsâ€™ model updates. However, we will explore the impact of the fraction of selected clients in a training round and aggregation rule on FLForensics.

Training-phase defenses are insufficient:Â  Training-phase defenses use robust FL methods or malicious-client detection methods to prevent malicious clients from poisoning a global model during training. TableÂ 18 in Appendix shows that robust FL methodsâ€“such as TrimÂ [7], MedianÂ [7], FLTrustÂ [9], and FLAMEÂ [8]â€“are insufficient. In particular, ASRs of the considered poisoning attacks are still high in many cases. TableÂ 2 shows that FLDetector, a malicious-client detection method, cannot accurately detect malicious clients during training in many cases. These training-phase defenses are still vulnerable to poisoning attacks because the clientsâ€™ training data are non-iid, making it hard to accurately distinguish between malicious clientsâ€™ and benign clientsâ€™ model updates.

FLForensicsÂ is effective:Â  TableÂ 3 shows the results of FLForensicsÂ and compared poison-forensics methods under different attacks and datasets.
We observe that FLForensicsÂ can accurately identify malicious clients, achieving a DACC of 1 or nearly 1 in all experiments. The FPR of FLForensicsÂ is 0 or close to 0 in most cases, with four exceptions (Sentiment140 dataset under Scaling attack, Sentiment140 dataset under Edge attack, CIFAR-10 dataset under Edge attack, and ImageNet-Fruits dataset under Edge attack), for which FPR is around 3%, i.e., one to three benign clients are misclassified as malicious. We can observe that our FLForensicsÂ can detect all the malicious clients even when the scaling factor is close to 1. Note that the server can also re-train a global model with small communication/computation cost for the clients using FedRecoverÂ [18].

Attack frequency:Â 
One adaptive attack is that each malicious client performs attacks only in some certain selected training rounds, violating the poisoning attack definition in DefinitionÂ 1. In particular, when a malicious client does not perform attack in a training round, it calculates its model update based on the clean local training data. TableÂ 11a shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the malicious clients perform the Scaling attack in every eğ‘’e training rounds, where eğ‘’e ranges from 1 to 10.
We find that when the malicious clients perform attack every 10 or more rounds, FLForensicsÂ cannot accurately detect the malicious clients. This is because the attacks are ineffective, i.e., ASRs are less than 12%. In other words, FLForensicsÂ can accurately detect malicious clients for the adaptive attack once it is effective, i.e., attack frequently and achieve high ASRs.

Attack probability:Â 
Other than performing attacks periodically in every eğ‘’e training rounds, an attacker can also choose to perform attack in each training round with a certain probability. Such attack may be more stealthy and harder to trace back. TableÂ 11b shows the results when a malicious client launches the Scaling attack with a probability pğ‘p in each training round, where pğ‘p ranges from 0.2 to 1.0.
We observe that ASR decreases as pğ‘p decreases. FLForensicsÂ accurately detects malicious clients when pâ‰¥0.5ğ‘0.5p\geq 0.5, with a FPR not exceeding 1.25%. When p=0.2ğ‘0.2p=0.2, the attack has an ASR of 20%. Since the attack is less effective in this scenario, FLForensicsÂ has a higher FNR at detecting malicious clients. However, FLForensicsÂ still achieves a small FPR, with at most one benign client misclassified as malicious.

FollowingÂ [16], we place the trigger at the upper right corner of an image by default. This is because the previous work was for centralized learning, while our results are for FL.

To investigate the performance of FLForensicsÂ under different trigger values, we vary the pixel value of the trigger, where the trigger shape is from Bagdasaryan et al.Â [16]. Specifically, we select three different RGB values for each pixel of the trigger, i.e., (255, 255, 255), (204, 204, 204), and (0, 0, 0). Datasets:Â 
We use five benchmark datasets in our experiments, comprising four image datasets and one text dataset. TableÂ 1 provides an overview of the dataset statistics.

FL training settings:Â  Following prior workÂ [9, 4], we assume 100 clients in total. A unique characteristic of FL is that the local training data are not identically distributed (non-iid) across clients. We use the method inÂ [4] to simulate non-iid settings, and the degree of non-iid is set to 0.5 for CIFAR-10, Fashion-MNIST, MNIST, and ImageNet-Fruits. The details of simulating non-iid can be found in AppendixÂ A.6. For the Sentiment140 dataset, we divide the users into 100 groups uniformly at random. Each group is considered as a client, whose local training data is the union of the training tweets of the users in the group. Usersâ€™ tweets are non-iid, so the clientsâ€™ local training data are also non-iid. Therefore, we do not need to simulate the non-iid setting for this dataset. We train a ResNet-20Â [30] classifier for CIFAR-10, a CNN classifier for Fashion-MNIST and MNIST (the architecture is shown in TableÂ 15 in Appendix), a LSTMÂ [31] classifier for Sentiment140, and a ResNet-50Â [30] classifier for ImageNet-Fruits dataset.

The default parameter settings (e.g., learning rates, batch sizes, global rounds, and local training epochs) are shown in TableÂ 16 in Appendix. By default, the server selects all clients in each training round and uses the average aggregation rule FedAvgÂ [1] to aggregate the clientsâ€™ model updates. However, we will explore the impact of the fraction of selected clients in a training round and aggregation rule on FLForensics.

In particular, ASRs of the considered poisoning attacks are still high in many cases. TableÂ 2 shows that FLDetector, a malicious-client detection method, cannot accurately detect malicious clients during training in many cases. Moreover, all benign clients are correctly detected as benign (i.e., FPR=0) when the fraction of malicious clients varies from 10% to 40%. We note that when the fraction of malicious clients is small, the attacks are not effectiveÂ [4], and thus we consider at least 10% of malicious clients.

Impact of degree of non-iid:Â  Based on the results in TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ works well across different degrees of non-iid. In particular, FLForensicsÂ achieves 0 FPR and at most 15% FNR across different settings of degree of non-iid. Note that 0.1 degree of non-iid represents the iid setting. FLForensicsÂ works well for non-iid because it is explicitly designed to take non-iid into consideration.

Impact of aggregation rules:Â  Based on TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ can accurately trace back the malicious clients when the server uses different Byzantine-robust aggregation rules during training. We note that these Byzantine-robust aggregation rules are not effective at defending against the poisoning attacks in our experimental settings, as shown in TableÂ 18 in Appendix.
Our results show that FLForensicsÂ is complementary with training-phase defenses and can be used together with them.
In TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ achieves slightly higher FPR when FLAME is used as the aggregation rule. This is because Scaling attack is less effective for FLAME and FLForensicsÂ incorrectly identifies some Category I benign clients as malicious.

Impact of fraction of selected clients:Â Based on TableÂ 10, FLForensicsÂ works well even if the server selects a small fraction of clients in each training round. The reason is that once a malicious client appears in multiple check-point training rounds, FLForensicsÂ can accumulate its influences to distinguish it with benign clients. Note that in this experiment, we save all training rounds as check points so a malicious client appears in multiple of them.

Impact of scaling factor Î³ğ›¾\gamma:Â  Based on the results in TableÂ 10, we observe that FLForensicsÂ works well for a wide range of scaling factors used by the Scaling attack. The reason is that once the Scaling attack is effective, FLForensicsÂ can identify the malicious clients. Previous workÂ [16] shows that the higher the scaling factor, the more effective the attack, but it also makes the attack more susceptible to detection. We can observe that our FLForensicsÂ can detect all the malicious clients even when the scaling factor is close to 1. In such cases, methods (e.g., FLDetector) that rely on the magnitudes of clientsâ€™ model updates to detect malicious clients often fail.

Recovering from attacks after FLForensics:Â  After detecting malicious clients, a server can re-train a global model using the remaining clients to recover from attacks. We pick the case in TableÂ 3, for which FLForensicsÂ has the largest FNR, to show recovery results. On CIFAR-10 dataset under Edge attack, the original global model has testing accuracy 81.9% and ASR 17.4%; and after detecting malicious clients and re-training a global model, these numbers change to 82.8% and 5.6%, respectively. Note that the server can also re-train a global model with small communication/computation cost for the clients using FedRecoverÂ [18].

Attack frequency:Â 
One adaptive attack is that each malicious client performs attacks only in some certain selected training rounds, violating the poisoning attack definition in DefinitionÂ 1. In particular, when a malicious client does not perform attack in a training round, it calculates its model update based on the clean local training data. TableÂ 11a shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the malicious clients perform the Scaling attack in every eğ‘’e training rounds, where eğ‘’e ranges from 1 to 10.
We find that when the malicious clients perform attack every 10 or more rounds, FLForensicsÂ cannot accurately detect the malicious clients. This is because the attacks are ineffective, i.e., ASRs are less than 12%. In other words, FLForensicsÂ can accurately detect malicious clients for the adaptive attack once it is effective, i.e., attack frequently and achieve high ASRs.

Attack probability:Â 
Other than performing attacks periodically in every eğ‘’e training rounds, an attacker can also choose to perform attack in each training round with a certain probability. Such attack may be more stealthy and harder to trace back. TableÂ 11b shows the results when a malicious client launches the Scaling attack with a probability pğ‘p in each training round, where pğ‘p ranges from 0.2 to 1.0.
We observe that ASR decreases as pğ‘p decreases. FLForensicsÂ accurately detects malicious clients when pâ‰¥0.5ğ‘0.5p\geq 0.5, with a FPR not exceeding 1.25%. When p=0.2ğ‘0.2p=0.2, the attack has an ASR of 20%. Since the attack is less effective in this scenario, FLForensicsÂ has a higher FNR at detecting malicious clients. However, FLForensicsÂ still achieves a small FPR, with at most one benign client misclassified as malicious.

Trigger location:Â 
FollowingÂ [16], we place the trigger at the upper right corner of an image by default. TableÂ 11c illustrates the performance of FLForensicsÂ when the Scaling attack places the trigger at different locations, where UR, LR, UL, and LL represent the trigger is at the upper right corner, lower right corner, upper left corner, and lower left corner of an image, respectively. Note that the trigger in these experiments is the same as that inÂ [16].
We also evaluate adding the trigger at a random location of each image in each training round, which corresponds to the â€˜Randomâ€™ row. The results show that when the triggerâ€™s location is fixed, the attack is generally more effective, with only the UL trigger location having a lower ASR, and FLForensicsÂ can correctly identify malicious clients in such scenarios. When the attacker introduces the trigger at random locations, the attack becomes less effective, and thus FLForensicsÂ misses some malicious clients (FNR is around 30%). Our results show that FLForensicsÂ performs well across various trigger locations that achieve high ASRs. We note that previous workÂ [34] showed that trigger location including random location does not have much impact on an attackâ€™s ASR. We have a different observation in our experiments. This is because the previous work was for centralized learning, while our results are for FL.

Trigger value:Â 
To investigate the performance of FLForensicsÂ under different trigger values, we vary the pixel value of the trigger, where the trigger shape is from Bagdasaryan et al.Â [16]. Specifically, we select three different RGB values for each pixel of the trigger, i.e., (255, 255, 255), (204, 204, 204), and (0, 0, 0). Additionally, we use a random trigger, each pixel of which has random RGB values. TableÂ 11e shows these triggers and the corresponding performance of FLForensics. Our results indicate that once the attack is effective, FLForensicsÂ can accurately trace back malicious clients. FLForensicsÂ misses all the malicious clients when the trigger value is (0, 0, 0). This is because this trigger value is ineffective at all, i.e., ASR=0.

Trigger size:Â 
TableÂ 11d shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the Scaling attack uses different trigger sizes, where the trigger is a white square located at the upper right corner. We observe that as the trigger size increases, ASR also increases. When the trigger size is 2Ã—\times2, the attack has almost no effect, leading to inaccurate detection of malicious clients for FLForensics. However, when the trigger size is greater than or equal to 3Ã—\times3, FLForensicsÂ can correctly identify all malicious clients, even with an ASR of only 14.2%. These results show that once the trigger size is large enough to make the attack somewhat effective, our FLForensicsÂ performs well.

Using true input as non-target input:Â  In our experiments, we use a random input (e.g., a random image) as a non-target input in FLForensics. When a true input with the target label is available, the server can also use it as the non-target input. TableÂ 12 compares the results when FLForensicsÂ uses a random input or true input as the non-target input on the five datasets and three attacks.
We find that random inputs and true inputs achieve comparable results in most cases, except several cases, for which true inputs achieve slightly lower FPRs. These results indicate that if a true input with the target label from the learning taskâ€™s data distribution is available, the server can use it as the non-target input.

Extending FLForensicsÂ to centralized learning:Â  Our FLForensicsÂ can also be extended to centralized learning. Forensics for clean-label targeted attacks:

Â  We focus on tracing back dirty-label attacks in this work, where the poisoned training examples have the same label as the target label. We find that for clean-label attacks, where only the training data is poisoned without changing their labels, FLForensics can still effectively trace back the malicious clients. This is because it leverages clientsâ€™ model updates instead of their local training data. Once the model updates are backdoored, FLForensics can trace back. Â  In this work, we focus on forensics for targeted poisoning attacks. An interesting future work is to extend our FLForensicsÂ to untargeted poisoning attacksÂ

and a non-target input. This is because the misclassified input in an untargeted poisoning attack is also a non-target input.

Extra privacy concerns of storing checkpoints:

Â  FLForensicsÂ requires the server to save checkpoints during training process in order to trace back malicious clients. These checkpoints include the global model parameters and clientsâ€™ local model updates. Therefore, it is worth discussing the potential privacy concerns associated with storing these information. In SectionÂ

, we assume that the server is not compromised by an attacker. Under this threat model, storing checkpoints on the server does not pose any extra privacy issues. However, if there is a risk of server compromise, the additional privacy concerns introduced by storing checkpoints depend on whether the server is compromised and when the compromise occurs. If the server is compromised before the training starts, the attacker can easily access and save the checkpoints, and thus storing them would not introduce additional privacy concerns. On the other hand, if the server is compromised after training, we acknowledge that storing checkpoints may raise extra privacy concerns since the attacker can access them.

Datasets:Â 
We use five benchmark datasets in our experiments, comprising four image datasets and one text dataset. TableÂ 1 provides an overview of the dataset statistics.

FL training settings:Â  Following prior workÂ [9, 4], we assume 100 clients in total. A unique characteristic of FL is that the local training data are not identically distributed (non-iid) across clients. We use the method inÂ [4] to simulate non-iid settings, and the degree of non-iid is set to 0.5 for CIFAR-10, Fashion-MNIST, MNIST, and ImageNet-Fruits. The details of simulating non-iid can be found in AppendixÂ A.6. For the Sentiment140 dataset, we divide the users into 100 groups uniformly at random. Each group is considered as a client, whose local training data is the union of the training tweets of the users in the group. Usersâ€™ tweets are non-iid, so the clientsâ€™ local training data are also non-iid. Therefore, we do not need to simulate the non-iid setting for this dataset. In particular, ASRs of the considered poisoning attacks are still high in many cases. In our comparison, we give advantages to FLForensics-G and PF by assuming that they have access to the local training data. We also conduct experiments where they use clientsâ€™ model updates sent to the server. TableÂ 17 in Appendix shows the results. We can observe that FLForensics-G performs worse, while PF achieves similar performance to using the local training data.

The reason is that once a malicious client appears in multiple check-point training rounds, FLForensicsÂ can accumulate its influences to distinguish it with benign clients. Attack frequency:Â 
One adaptive attack is that each malicious client performs attacks only in some certain selected training rounds, violating the poisoning attack definition in DefinitionÂ 1. In particular, when a malicious client does not perform attack in a training round, it calculates its model update based on the clean local training data. This is because the attacks are ineffective, i.e., ASRs are less than 12%. In other words, FLForensicsÂ can accurately detect malicious clients for the adaptive attack once it is effective, i.e., attack frequently and achieve high ASRs.

We observe that ASR decreases as pğ‘p decreases. FLForensicsÂ accurately detects malicious clients when pâ‰¥0.5ğ‘0.5p\geq 0.5, with a FPR not exceeding 1.25%. We use five benchmark datasets in our experiments, comprising four image datasets and one text dataset. TableÂ 1 provides an overview of the dataset statistics.

Each group is considered as a client, whose local training data is the union of the training tweets of the users in the group. Usersâ€™ tweets are non-iid, so the clientsâ€™ local training data are also non-iid. Therefore, we do not need to simulate the non-iid setting for this dataset. We train a ResNet-20Â [30] classifier for CIFAR-10, a CNN classifier for Fashion-MNIST and MNIST (the architecture is shown in TableÂ 15 in Appendix), a LSTMÂ [31] classifier for Sentiment140, and a ResNet-50Â [30] classifier for ImageNet-Fruits dataset.

The default parameter settings (e.g., learning rates, batch sizes, global rounds, and local training epochs) are shown in TableÂ 16 in Appendix. By default, the server selects all clients in each training round and uses the average aggregation rule FedAvgÂ [1] to aggregate the clientsâ€™ model updates. However, we will explore the impact of the fraction of selected clients in a training round and aggregation rule on FLForensics.

Training-phase defenses are insufficient:Â  Training-phase defenses use robust FL methods or malicious-client detection methods to prevent malicious clients from poisoning a global model during training. TableÂ 18 in Appendix shows that robust FL methodsâ€“such as TrimÂ [7], MedianÂ [7], FLTrustÂ [9], and FLAMEÂ [8]â€“are insufficient. In particular, ASRs of the considered poisoning attacks are still high in many cases. TableÂ 2 shows that FLDetector, a malicious-client detection method, cannot accurately detect malicious clients during training in many cases. These training-phase defenses are still vulnerable to poisoning attacks because the clientsâ€™ training data are non-iid, making it hard to accurately distinguish between malicious clientsâ€™ and benign clientsâ€™ model updates.

FLForensicsÂ is effective:Â  TableÂ 3 shows the results of FLForensicsÂ and compared poison-forensics methods under different attacks and datasets.
We observe that FLForensicsÂ can accurately identify malicious clients, achieving a DACC of 1 or nearly 1 in all experiments. The FPR of FLForensicsÂ is 0 or close to 0 in most cases, with four exceptions (Sentiment140 dataset under Scaling attack, Sentiment140 dataset under Edge attack, CIFAR-10 dataset under Edge attack, and ImageNet-Fruits dataset under Edge attack), for which FPR is around 3%, i.e., one to three benign clients are misclassified as malicious. Similarly, FNR is also 0 or close to 0, with only two exceptions.

FLForensicsÂ outperforms the compared poison-forensics methods:Â 
TableÂ 3 also shows that our FLForensicsÂ outperforms the compared poison-forensics methods. First, FLForensicsÂ outperforms FLForensics-A, particularly evident in FLForensicsâ€™s significantly lower FPR compared to FLForensics-A. For instance, FLForensicsÂ exhibits a FPR of 0 under all attacks on CIFAR-10, while FLForensics-Aâ€™s FPR consistently exceeds 10%, indicating that at least 8 benign clients are incorrectly classified as malicious clients by FLForensics-A. This result demonstrates that using only the target input xğ‘¥{x} is unable to distinguish between malicious and Category I benign clients. Second, FLForensicsÂ outperforms PF and FLForensics-G because they were not designed for FL. In our comparison, we give advantages to FLForensics-G and PF by assuming that they have access to the local training data. We also conduct experiments where they use clientsâ€™ model updates sent to the server. TableÂ 17 in Appendix shows the results. We can observe that FLForensics-G performs worse, while PF achieves similar performance to using the local training data.

Impact of number of check points and storage overhead:Â  TableÂ 4 shows the impact of the number of check points on FLForensics. We observe a trade-off between storage overhead and poison-forensics performance. In particular, when a server saves more check points, which incurs more storage overhead, the server can more accurately detect the malicious clients. We also note that the storage overhead is acceptable for a powerful server to achieve good poison-forensics performance.
TableÂ 5 shows the storage overhead for different datasets in our default settings.
For instance, saving 150 check points for CIFAR-10 requires 15.22GB storage, which is acceptable for a powerful server like a data center.

Impact of fraction of malicious clients:Â TableÂ 6 shows the impact of fraction of malicious clients on FLForensics. We observe that FLForensicsÂ works well when a large fraction of clients are malicious. For instance, only 5% of malicious clients are identified as benign even if 40% of clients are malicious. Moreover, all benign clients are correctly detected as benign (i.e., FPR=0) when the fraction of malicious clients varies from 10% to 40%. We note that when the fraction of malicious clients is small, the attacks are not effectiveÂ [4], and thus we consider at least 10% of malicious clients.

Impact of degree of non-iid:Â  Based on the results in TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ works well across different degrees of non-iid. In particular, FLForensicsÂ achieves 0 FPR and at most 15% FNR across different settings of degree of non-iid. Note that 0.1 degree of non-iid represents the iid setting. FLForensicsÂ works well for non-iid because it is explicitly designed to take non-iid into consideration.

Impact of aggregation rules:Â  Based on TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ can accurately trace back the malicious clients when the server uses different Byzantine-robust aggregation rules during training. We note that these Byzantine-robust aggregation rules are not effective at defending against the poisoning attacks in our experimental settings, as shown in TableÂ 18 in Appendix.
Our results show that FLForensicsÂ is complementary with training-phase defenses and can be used together with them.
In TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ achieves slightly higher FPR when FLAME is used as the aggregation rule. This is because Scaling attack is less effective for FLAME and FLForensicsÂ incorrectly identifies some Category I benign clients as malicious.

Impact of fraction of selected clients:Â Based on TableÂ 10, FLForensicsÂ works well even if the server selects a small fraction of clients in each training round. The reason is that once a malicious client appears in multiple check-point training rounds, FLForensicsÂ can accumulate its influences to distinguish it with benign clients. Note that in this experiment, we save all training rounds as check points so a malicious client appears in multiple of them.

Impact of scaling factor Î³ğ›¾\gamma:Â  Based on the results in TableÂ 10, we observe that FLForensicsÂ works well for a wide range of scaling factors used by the Scaling attack. The reason is that once the Scaling attack is effective, FLForensicsÂ can identify the malicious clients. Previous workÂ [16] shows that the higher the scaling factor, the more effective the attack, but it also makes the attack more susceptible to detection. We can observe that our FLForensicsÂ can detect all the malicious clients even when the scaling factor is close to 1. In such cases, methods (e.g., FLDetector) that rely on the magnitudes of clientsâ€™ model updates to detect malicious clients often fail.

Recovering from attacks after FLForensics:Â  After detecting malicious clients, a server can re-train a global model using the remaining clients to recover from attacks. We pick the case in TableÂ 3, for which FLForensicsÂ has the largest FNR, to show recovery results. On CIFAR-10 dataset under Edge attack, the original global model has testing accuracy 81.9% and ASR 17.4%; and after detecting malicious clients and re-training a global model, these numbers change to 82.8% and 5.6%, respectively. Note that the server can also re-train a global model with small communication/computation cost for the clients using FedRecoverÂ [18].

Attack frequency:Â 
One adaptive attack is that each malicious client performs attacks only in some certain selected training rounds, violating the poisoning attack definition in DefinitionÂ 1. In particular, when a malicious client does not perform attack in a training round, it calculates its model update based on the clean local training data. TableÂ 11a shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the malicious clients perform the Scaling attack in every eğ‘’e training rounds, where eğ‘’e ranges from 1 to 10.
We find that when the malicious clients perform attack every 10 or more rounds, FLForensicsÂ cannot accurately detect the malicious clients. This is because the attacks are ineffective, i.e., ASRs are less than 12%. In other words, FLForensicsÂ can accurately detect malicious clients for the adaptive attack once it is effective, i.e., attack frequently and achieve high ASRs.

Attack probability:Â 
Other than performing attacks periodically in every eğ‘’e training rounds, an attacker can also choose to perform attack in each training round with a certain probability. Such attack may be more stealthy and harder to trace back. TableÂ 11b shows the results when a malicious client launches the Scaling attack with a probability pğ‘p in each training round, where pğ‘p ranges from 0.2 to 1.0.
We observe that ASR decreases as pğ‘p decreases. FLForensicsÂ accurately detects malicious clients when pâ‰¥0.5ğ‘0.5p\geq 0.5, with a FPR not exceeding 1.25%. When p=0.2ğ‘0.2p=0.2, the attack has an ASR of 20%. Since the attack is less effective in this scenario, FLForensicsÂ has a higher FNR at detecting malicious clients. However, FLForensicsÂ still achieves a small FPR, with at most one benign client misclassified as malicious.

FollowingÂ [16], we place the trigger at the upper right corner of an image by default. TableÂ 11c illustrates the performance of FLForensicsÂ when the Scaling attack places the trigger at different locations, where UR, LR, UL, and LL represent the trigger is at the upper right corner, lower right corner, upper left corner, and lower left corner of an image, respectively. Note that the trigger in these experiments is the same as that inÂ [16].

Our results show that FLForensicsÂ performs well across various trigger locations that achieve high ASRs. This is because the previous work was for centralized learning, while our results are for FL.

Trigger value:Â 
To investigate the performance of FLForensicsÂ under different trigger values, we vary the pixel value of the trigger, where the trigger shape is from Bagdasaryan et al.Â [16]. Specifically, we select three different RGB values for each pixel of the trigger, i.e., (255, 255, 255), (204, 204, 204), and (0, 0, 0). TableÂ 11d shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the Scaling attack uses different trigger sizes, where the trigger is a white square located at the upper right corner. FLForensicsÂ incurs space overhead for the server due to storing global models and clientsâ€™ model updates in the check points. The space overhead is linear to the model size, number of check points, and the number of clients selected to participate in each training round. This storage overhead is acceptable for a powerful server. In SectionÂ 8, we discuss the potential privacy concerns of storing checkpoints.

Datasets:Â 
We use five benchmark datasets in our experiments, comprising four image datasets and one text dataset. TableÂ 1 provides an overview of the dataset statistics.

FL training settings:Â  Following prior workÂ [9, 4], we assume 100 clients in total. A unique characteristic of FL is that the local training data are not identically distributed (non-iid) across clients. We use the method inÂ [4] to simulate non-iid settings, and the degree of non-iid is set to 0.5 for CIFAR-10, Fashion-MNIST, MNIST, and ImageNet-Fruits. The details of simulating non-iid can be found in AppendixÂ A.6. For the Sentiment140 dataset, we divide the users into 100 groups uniformly at random. Each group is considered as a client, whose local training data is the union of the training tweets of the users in the group. Usersâ€™ tweets are non-iid, so the clientsâ€™ local training data are also non-iid. Therefore, we do not need to simulate the non-iid setting for this dataset. We train a ResNet-20Â [30] classifier for CIFAR-10, a CNN classifier for Fashion-MNIST and MNIST (the architecture is shown in TableÂ 15 in Appendix), a LSTMÂ [31] classifier for Sentiment140, and a ResNet-50Â [30] classifier for ImageNet-Fruits dataset.

The default parameter settings (e.g., learning rates, batch sizes, global rounds, and local training epochs) are shown in TableÂ 16 in Appendix. By default, the server selects all clients in each training round and uses the average aggregation rule FedAvgÂ [1] to aggregate the clientsâ€™ model updates. However, we will explore the impact of the fraction of selected clients in a training round and aggregation rule on FLForensics.

Training-phase defenses are insufficient:Â  Training-phase defenses use robust FL methods or malicious-client detection methods to prevent malicious clients from poisoning a global model during training. TableÂ 18 in Appendix shows that robust FL methodsâ€“such as TrimÂ [7], MedianÂ [7], FLTrustÂ [9], and FLAMEÂ [8]â€“are insufficient. In particular, ASRs of the considered poisoning attacks are still high in many cases. TableÂ 2 shows that FLDetector, a malicious-client detection method, cannot accurately detect malicious clients during training in many cases. These training-phase defenses are still vulnerable to poisoning attacks because the clientsâ€™ training data are non-iid, making it hard to accurately distinguish between malicious clientsâ€™ and benign clientsâ€™ model updates.

FLForensicsÂ is effective:Â  TableÂ 3 shows the results of FLForensicsÂ and compared poison-forensics methods under different attacks and datasets.
We observe that FLForensicsÂ can accurately identify malicious clients, achieving a DACC of 1 or nearly 1 in all experiments. The FPR of FLForensicsÂ is 0 or close to 0 in most cases, with four exceptions (Sentiment140 dataset under Scaling attack, Sentiment140 dataset under Edge attack, CIFAR-10 dataset under Edge attack, and ImageNet-Fruits dataset under Edge attack), for which FPR is around 3%, i.e., one to three benign clients are misclassified as malicious. Similarly, FNR is also 0 or close to 0, with only two exceptions.

FLForensicsÂ outperforms the compared poison-forensics methods:Â 
TableÂ 3 also shows that our FLForensicsÂ outperforms the compared poison-forensics methods. First, FLForensicsÂ outperforms FLForensics-A, particularly evident in FLForensicsâ€™s significantly lower FPR compared to FLForensics-A. For instance, FLForensicsÂ exhibits a FPR of 0 under all attacks on CIFAR-10, while FLForensics-Aâ€™s FPR consistently exceeds 10%, indicating that at least 8 benign clients are incorrectly classified as malicious clients by FLForensics-A. This result demonstrates that using only the target input xğ‘¥{x} is unable to distinguish between malicious and Category I benign clients. Second, FLForensicsÂ outperforms PF and FLForensics-G because they were not designed for FL. In our comparison, we give advantages to FLForensics-G and PF by assuming that they have access to the local training data. We also conduct experiments where they use clientsâ€™ model updates sent to the server. TableÂ 17 in Appendix shows the results. We can observe that FLForensics-G performs worse, while PF achieves similar performance to using the local training data.

Impact of number of check points and storage overhead:Â  TableÂ 4 shows the impact of the number of check points on FLForensics. We observe a trade-off between storage overhead and poison-forensics performance. In particular, when a server saves more check points, which incurs more storage overhead, the server can more accurately detect the malicious clients. We also note that the storage overhead is acceptable for a powerful server to achieve good poison-forensics performance.
TableÂ 5 shows the storage overhead for different datasets in our default settings.
For instance, saving 150 check points for CIFAR-10 requires 15.22GB storage, which is acceptable for a powerful server like a data center.

Impact of fraction of malicious clients:Â TableÂ 6 shows the impact of fraction of malicious clients on FLForensics. We observe that FLForensicsÂ works well when a large fraction of clients are malicious. For instance, only 5% of malicious clients are identified as benign even if 40% of clients are malicious. Moreover, all benign clients are correctly detected as benign (i.e., FPR=0) when the fraction of malicious clients varies from 10% to 40%. We note that when the fraction of malicious clients is small, the attacks are not effectiveÂ [4], and thus we consider at least 10% of malicious clients.

Impact of degree of non-iid:Â  Based on the results in TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ works well across different degrees of non-iid. In particular, FLForensicsÂ achieves 0 FPR and at most 15% FNR across different settings of degree of non-iid. Note that 0.1 degree of non-iid represents the iid setting. FLForensicsÂ works well for non-iid because it is explicitly designed to take non-iid into consideration.

Impact of aggregation rules:Â  Based on TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ can accurately trace back the malicious clients when the server uses different Byzantine-robust aggregation rules during training. We note that these Byzantine-robust aggregation rules are not effective at defending against the poisoning attacks in our experimental settings, as shown in TableÂ 18 in Appendix.
Our results show that FLForensicsÂ is complementary with training-phase defenses and can be used together with them.
In TableÂ 8, FLForensicsÂ achieves slightly higher FPR when FLAME is used as the aggregation rule. This is because Scaling attack is less effective for FLAME and FLForensicsÂ incorrectly identifies some Category I benign clients as malicious.

Impact of fraction of selected clients:Â Based on TableÂ 10, FLForensicsÂ works well even if the server selects a small fraction of clients in each training round. The reason is that once a malicious client appears in multiple check-point training rounds, FLForensicsÂ can accumulate its influences to distinguish it with benign clients. Note that in this experiment, we save all training rounds as check points so a malicious client appears in multiple of them.

Impact of scaling factor Î³ğ›¾\gamma:Â  Based on the results in TableÂ 10, we observe that FLForensicsÂ works well for a wide range of scaling factors used by the Scaling attack. The reason is that once the Scaling attack is effective, FLForensicsÂ can identify the malicious clients. Previous workÂ [16] shows that the higher the scaling factor, the more effective the attack, but it also makes the attack more susceptible to detection. We can observe that our FLForensicsÂ can detect all the malicious clients even when the scaling factor is close to 1. In such cases, methods (e.g., FLDetector) that rely on the magnitudes of clientsâ€™ model updates to detect malicious clients often fail.

Recovering from attacks after FLForensics:Â  After detecting malicious clients, a server can re-train a global model using the remaining clients to recover from attacks. We pick the case in TableÂ 3, for which FLForensicsÂ has the largest FNR, to show recovery results. On CIFAR-10 dataset under Edge attack, the original global model has testing accuracy 81.9% and ASR 17.4%; and after detecting malicious clients and re-training a global model, these numbers change to 82.8% and 5.6%, respectively. Note that the server can also re-train a global model with small communication/computation cost for the clients using FedRecoverÂ [18].

Attack frequency:Â 
One adaptive attack is that each malicious client performs attacks only in some certain selected training rounds, violating the poisoning attack definition in DefinitionÂ 1. In particular, when a malicious client does not perform attack in a training round, it calculates its model update based on the clean local training data. TableÂ 11a shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the malicious clients perform the Scaling attack in every eğ‘’e training rounds, where eğ‘’e ranges from 1 to 10.
We find that when the malicious clients perform attack every 10 or more rounds, FLForensicsÂ cannot accurately detect the malicious clients. This is because the attacks are ineffective, i.e., ASRs are less than 12%. In other words, FLForensicsÂ can accurately detect malicious clients for the adaptive attack once it is effective, i.e., attack frequently and achieve high ASRs.

Attack probability:Â 
Other than performing attacks periodically in every eğ‘’e training rounds, an attacker can also choose to perform attack in each training round with a certain probability. Such attack may be more stealthy and harder to trace back. TableÂ 11b shows the results when a malicious client launches the Scaling attack with a probability pğ‘p in each training round, where pğ‘p ranges from 0.2 to 1.0.
We observe that ASR decreases as pğ‘p decreases. FLForensicsÂ accurately detects malicious clients when pâ‰¥0.5ğ‘0.5p\geq 0.5, with a FPR not exceeding 1.25%. When p=0.2ğ‘0.2p=0.2, the attack has an ASR of 20%. Since the attack is less effective in this scenario, FLForensicsÂ has a higher FNR at detecting malicious clients. However, FLForensicsÂ still achieves a small FPR, with at most one benign client misclassified as malicious.

Trigger location:Â 
FollowingÂ [16], we place the trigger at the upper right corner of an image by default. TableÂ 11c illustrates the performance of FLForensicsÂ when the Scaling attack places the trigger at different locations, where UR, LR, UL, and LL represent the trigger is at the upper right corner, lower right corner, upper left corner, and lower left corner of an image, respectively. Note that the trigger in these experiments is the same as that inÂ [16].
We also evaluate adding the trigger at a random location of each image in each training round, which corresponds to the â€˜Randomâ€™ row. The results show that when the triggerâ€™s location is fixed, the attack is generally more effective, with only the UL trigger location having a lower ASR, and FLForensicsÂ can correctly identify malicious clients in such scenarios. When the attacker introduces the trigger at random locations, the attack becomes less effective, and thus FLForensicsÂ misses some malicious clients (FNR is around 30%). Our results show that FLForensicsÂ performs well across various trigger locations that achieve high ASRs. We note that previous workÂ [34] showed that trigger location including random location does not have much impact on an attackâ€™s ASR. We have a different observation in our experiments. This is because the previous work was for centralized learning, while our results are for FL.

Trigger value:Â 
To investigate the performance of FLForensicsÂ under different trigger values, we vary the pixel value of the trigger, where the trigger shape is from Bagdasaryan et al.Â [16]. Specifically, we select three different RGB values for each pixel of the trigger, i.e., (255, 255, 255), (204, 204, 204), and (0, 0, 0). Additionally, we use a random trigger, each pixel of which has random RGB values. TableÂ 11e shows these triggers and the corresponding performance of FLForensics. Our results indicate that once the attack is effective, FLForensicsÂ can accurately trace back malicious clients. FLForensicsÂ misses all the malicious clients when the trigger value is (0, 0, 0). This is because this trigger value is ineffective at all, i.e., ASR=0.

Trigger size:Â 
TableÂ 11d shows the results of FLForensicsÂ when the Scaling attack uses different trigger sizes, where the trigger is a white square located at the upper right corner. We observe that as the trigger size increases, ASR also increases. When the trigger size is 2Ã—\times2, the attack has almost no effect, leading to inaccurate detection of malicious clients for FLForensics. However, when the trigger size is greater than or equal to 3Ã—\times3, FLForensicsÂ can correctly identify all malicious clients, even with an ASR of only 14.2%. These results show that once the trigger size is large enough to make the attack somewhat effective, our FLForensicsÂ performs well.

Using true input as non-target input:Â  In our experiments, we use a random input (e.g., a random image) as a non-target input in FLForensics. When a true input with the target label is available, the server can also use it as the non-target input. TableÂ 12 compares the results when FLForensicsÂ uses a random input or true input as the non-target input on the five datasets and three attacks.
We find that random inputs and true inputs achieve comparable results in most cases, except several cases, for which true inputs achieve slightly lower FPRs. These results indicate that if a true input with the target label from the learning taskâ€™s data distribution is available, the server can use it as the non-target input.
